Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Reaction Mechanisms, Performance Assessment, and Novel Mitigation Tools for Alkali-Silica Reaction in Concrete Structures

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project will advance the state of knowledge on deterioration mechanisms, damage mitigation, and prediction of service-life performance for concrete structures susceptible to alkali-silica reaction (ASR). The research approach decouples the three fundamental ASR reactions (silica dissolution, gelation, and swelling) and characterizes the thermodynamic equilibrium and kinetics of each reaction as a function of the chemistry (i.e., species concentrations and interactions) and physics (e.g., temperature, pressure, humidity) of the system. This will significantly clarify the reaction mechanisms and the role of aggregate mineralogy and binder compositions, and can lead to developing more efficient ASR inhibiting admixtures, and admixture delivery methods, applicable to new and existing structures. In addition, new testing and modeling tools are developed for rapid and reliable assessment of the ASR risk and for quantitative prediction of the durability performance of concrete containing potentially reactive aggregates. Finally, ASR in emerging alkali-activated concretes is studied which allows improved reliability and market acceptance of these green materials. The project integrates multi-scale experimentation with multi-scale (geochemical, reactive-transport, and performance prediction) modeling to efficiently achieve these research goals. In addition to advancing the ASR science, the findings could be of substantial value in accelerating the synthesis and utilization of new pozzolans, geopolymers, and other high performance silica-based materials.

Alkali-silica reaction continues to be a major durability problem of concrete. The resulting expansion, cracking, and loss of serviceability impose enormous maintenance and reconstruction costs for bridges, pavements, dams, and other civil infrastructure. This project performs hypothesis-driven basic research to support transformative advancements in durability, service-life extension, and as such, sustainability and resiliency of concrete infrastructure susceptible to ASR. Through fostering collaborations with national and international institutes, the project provides state-of-the-art research training for graduate and undergraduate students to become the next generation scientists and engineers. The project's technical components are well integrated with teaching and outreach activities, including (a) implementing cooperative problem-based learning to improve creative thinking and teamwork skills of undergraduate students; (b) development and dissemination of free interactive e-learning modules to familiarize students, faculty, and practicing engineers with advanced materials characterization techniques; and (c) promoting engineering at high school level to attract and engage under-represented students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alkali silica reaction (ASR) is a leading cause of deterioration in many concrete elements and structures, including building exteriors, foundations, pavements, bridges, walls, dams, and power plant structures. ASR undermines the safety, serviceability, durability, and sustainability of structures, and imposes significant costs to owners and users of such structures. ASR occurs when relatively abundant siliceous aggregates dissolve into the highly alkaline pore solution of concrete and form a silica gel, which swells and causes stress development and cracking in concrete.

            This CAREER award led to advancing the knowledge on ASR reaction mechanisms and products (ASR gel), as well as development of novel low-cost chemical admixtures to efficiently mitigate ASR without producing negative side effects on other properties of concrete. Specifically, the project shed light on the effect of calcium on silica dissolution and gelation; linked ASR gel composition with its rheological, swelling, and mechanical properties (this information is highly useful for ASR damage prediction models); provided quantitative tools to predict ASR expansion as a function of aggregate reactivity, concrete alkalinity, temperature, and availability of moisture; and identified a set of unique organic and inorganic salts that when admixed into concrete in a powder or dissolved/liquid form, effectively mitigate ASR by regulating the alkalinity/pH of concrete.

            The project findings were published in ten journal papers, five conference papers, four Masters and Ph.D. theses, and 38 conference presentations. Four additional journal papers and a Ph.D. thesis are currently in preparation. An international patent application was filed for the ASR mitigation admixture technology and discussions are well underway with several potential licensees to bring this technology into concrete market. The project website (https://alkalisilica.weebly.com/) includes information on all aspects of the project including major research findings, educational activities and products, a list of journal and conference publications and student theses with links for free access to these publications, and a list of current and former graduate students that contributed to this project.

            Four Ph.D., two Masters, and nine undergraduate (REU) students received training during this project. These included two women grad students and two underrepresented male REU students. The graduate students received extensive and state-of-the-art research training and were mentored in disseminating the research findings through authorship of journal and conference publications and presentations. The REU students were trained in proportioning and casting of mortar and concrete mixtures and in performing standard ASTM testing on such mixtures. This experience led the two underrepresented REU students to continue for graduate school in civil engineering.

            A required Civil Engineering Materials laboratory course was completely redesigned as a result of this project to improve the creative thinking and teamwork skills of undergraduate students. This course is taken by over 200 Civil and Architectural Engineering students at Penn State every year. The PI provided mentored teaching experience for 17 graduate student TAs who taught this course during the period of performance of this project. A new graduate course titled “Characterization of Cementitious Materials” was developed and is offered for the second time in Spring 2021. The course covers introduction, sample preparation, electron microscopy, basics of crystallography, X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, mercury porosimetry, and gas adsorption and condensation in porous media. Each lecture includes basic principles behind each technique, proper sample preparation, instrument setup, testing and data collection, and analysis of the results. The course modules are available for free public access via the project website.

            To attract and engage women to studying and pursuing careers in civil engineering, two 6th-12th grade workshops were developed and delivered through Penn State’s annual “Expanding Your Horizons (EYH) STEM Career Day for Young Women”. The workshops welcomed approximately 120 middle-school and high-school aged girls from central Pennsylvania. The workshops familiarized students with the basic material properties of concrete, its applications, how it is practiced in the field, and why studying concrete is significant. Most importantly, the workshops encouraged girls to enter a STEM field.
